I have taken an opportunity this morning to review the motion to intervene as well as the   
response filed by the State, a review of the pleadings attached to the State's response, and the reply from the requested interveners. These are attorneys   
intervening on behalf of David Morgan and Terri Jo Neff.   
They have specifically requested the following relief:  The first request is that at least one reporter be allowed to be present in the courtroom during the proceedings when the jury is present to the extent possible.   
I find no objection to their -- the   
permission of one reporter or even two reporters being present in the courtroom during the proceedings;   
assuming all other safety precautions are taken with respect to the health concerns of the pandemic. I think that we have authorization to have up to 50 people in the courtroom at this time.   
Assuming that all other safety precautions are met, to wit; masks and social   
distancing, that request is not unreasonable, and it is not objected to by the State.   
Therefore, with respect to the motion to intervene, I am permitting the intervention to address the request sought by the First Amendment Law Firm, and I am granting the first request, to wit; that reporter -- a reporter or two reporters may be present, all other health considerations under phase two of the pandemic guidelines, which I believe we are still under are met.   
With respect to the second request of the interveners, that the Court make public the name of the prospective jurors during voir dire, this matter will be denied.   
Consistent with the previous request not to permit televising or photography of the jury or the trial during its proceeding, the Court has undertaken a system of not making public the names of prospective jurors or final jurors to a jury trial in Cochise   
County.   
The names of jurors are made known to the parties, to the defense as well as to the State, for the purpose of permitting the attorneys and the   
defendant to know who precisely is prospectively going

1 to serve on the jury, as well as who they might finally 2 select to serve on the jury. 3 That is to ensure that the defendant has 4 a fair trial, and that will be made known and is made 5 known the defendant for the purpose of ensuring that 6 the defendant's trial rights are ensured. 7 That same right does not extend in any 8 similar capacity to the press. They have not got the 9 interest that the defendant does, and certainly it is 10 not superior to the right of the -- the defendant's 11 right to a fair trial. 12 The concerns that the jurors may feel 13 pressured if their names are known, if they are 14 particularly made known to the press and particularly 15 under pressure, particularly I agree with the State in 16 a small community that they may feel that their privacy 17 is compromised in some way, or that they feel under 18 pressure to make particular decisions one way or the 19 other is a compelling reason why their identities 20 should not be made known to persons whose particular 21 constitutional rights are affected by this trial, such 22 as the defendant's. 23 Therefore, the names of prospective 24 jurors, as well as the names of jurors who are selected 25 to serve on the jury, will not be made public, and
